sentences.sentence: “I am afraid, Watson, that I shall have to go,” said Holmes, as we sat down together to our breakfast one morning.
“Go! Where to?”
“To Dartmoor; to King’s Pyland( 金斯皮兰，地名 ).”
I was not surprised.
Indeed, I was surprised that he had not already been mixed up( 卷入 ) in this extraordinary case,
which was the one topic of conversation throughout all of England.
For a whole day my companion had walked up and down the room with an expression of intense( 极度的 ) concentration on his face,
filling his pipe and smoking it and filling it again with the strongest black tobacco,
and absolutely deaf to any of my questions or remarks.
Fresh editions of every paper had been sent up by our newsagent( 送报员 ), only to be glanced over quickly and then thrown into a corner.
Yet, silent as he was, I knew perfectly well what he was brooding( 焦虑 ) over.
There was only one problem before the public which could challenge his powers of analysis,
and that was the remarkable disappearance of the favorite for the Wessex Cup, and the tragic murder of its trainer.
When, therefore, he suddenly announced his intention of setting out for the scene of the drama,
it was only what I had both expected and hoped for.
“I should be most happy to go down with you if I should not be in the way( 妨碍 ),” said I.
“My dear Watson, you would do me a great favor upon me by coming.
And I think that your time will not be wasted, for there are points about the case which promise to make it an absolutely unique one.
We have, I think, just time to catch our train at Paddington,
and I will go further into the matter on our journey.”
And so, an hour or so later, I found myself in the corner of a first-class carriage flying along to Exeter,
while Sherlock Holmes, with his sharp, eager face looking out from his famous outdoor hat with the flaps( 护耳 ) covering his ears,
read rapidly through the fresh newspapers which he had bought at Paddington Station.
We had left Reading far behind us before he finished the last of them and offered me a cigar.
“We are going well,” said he, looking out of the window and looking down at his watch.
“Our rate at present is fifty-three and a half miles an hour.”
“I have not observed the quarter-mile posts,” said I.
“Nor have I. But the telegraph posts upon this line are sixty yards apart, and the calculation is a simple one.
I presume( 料想 ) that you have looked into this matter of the murder of John Straker and the disappearance of Silver Blaze?”
“I have seen what the Telegraph and the Chronicle have to say.”
“It is one of those cases where it is more useful to sort through( 整理 ) the details we already have than to obtain fresh evidence.
The tragedy has been so uncommon, so complete, and of such personal importance to so many people,
that we have plenty of speculations( 推测 ), theories, and wild guesses—in fact, more than we need.
The difficulty is to separate the basic facts—absolutely known facts—from the theories of reporters.
Then, having this basis of facts, we shall see what inferences( 推断 ) may be drawn and what the keys to this mystery may be.
On Tuesday evening I received telegrams from both Colonel Ross, the owner of the horse, and Inspector Gregory, who is looking after the case, inviting my co-operation.”
“Tuesday evening!” I exclaimed( 惊叫 ).
“And this is Thursday morning. Why didn’t you go down yesterday?”
“Because I made a mistake, my dear Watson—which is, I am afraid,
a more common occurrence than any one would think who only knew me through your writings.
I could not believe it possible that the most remarkable horse in England could long remain hidden, especially in so remote and lonely a place as the north of Dartmoor.
From hour to hour yesterday I expected to hear that he had been found,
and that the man who had taken him was the murderer of John Straker.
But when another morning had come,
and I found that beyond the arrest of young Fitzroy Simpson nothing had been done,
I felt that it was time for me to take action.
Yet in some ways I feel that yesterday has not been wasted.”
“You have a theory, then?”
“At least I now understand the known facts of the case.
I shall list them for you, for nothing clears up a case so much as stating it to another person,
and I can hardly expect your co-operation if I do not show you the position from which we start.”
I lay back against the cushions, smoking my cigar, while Holmes gave me a brief review of the events which had led to our journey.
“Silver Blaze,” said he, “is a descendant( 后代 ) of the famous race-horse Somomy, and holds as brilliant a record as his famous ancestor.
He is now in his fifth year, and has brought in turn each of the prizes of the horse-racing world to Colonel Ross, his fortunate owner.
Up to the time of the catastrophe he was the favorite for the Wessex Cup, the betting being three to one on him.
He has always, however, been a prime favorite with the racing public, and has never yet disappointed them,
so that even at those odds( 投注赔率 ) enormous amounts of money have been bet on him.
It is obvious, therefore, that there were many people who had the strongest interest in preventing Silver Blaze from being there at the start of the race next Tuesday.
The fact was, of course, well understood at King’s Pyland( 金斯皮兰，地名 ), where the Colonel’s stable( 马房 ) is situated.
Every precaution( 预防措施 ) was taken to guard the favorite.
The trainer, John Straker, is a retired jockey( 赛马骑师 ) who rode for Colonel Ross before he became too heavy to ride in races.
He has served the Colonel for five years as jockey( 赛马骑师 ) and for seven as trainer,
and has always shown himself to be capable( 能干的 ), hard-working, and honest.
There were only three stable( 马房 ) boys working for him, because Colonel Ross only had four horses.
One of these stable( 马房 ) boys sat up each night in the stable( 马房 ), while the others slept in the loft( 阁楼 ).
All three bore excellent characters.
John Straker, who is a married man, lived in a small house about two hundred yards from the stables( 马房 ).
He has no children, keeps one maid, and earns enough money for his and his wife’s needs.
The surrounding country is very lonely,
but about half a mile to the north there is a small group of houses which have been built by a Tavistock builder for the use of people recovering from illness,
and others who may wish to enjoy the pure Dartmoor air.
Tavistock itself lies two miles to the west,
while across the moor( 荒野 ), also about two miles away, is the larger training stable( 马房 ) of Mapleton,
which belongs to Lord Backwater, and is managed by Silas Brown.
In every other direction the moor( 荒野 ) is completely wild: the only people you will find there are a few roaming( 流浪的 ) gypsies( 吉普赛人 ).
Such was the general situation last Monday night when the catastrophe occurred.”

article_info.previous: 罪犯们果然出现在地下室中，Holmes一行人成功抓捕罪犯。Holmes讲解整个案件的始末以及他是如何从蛛丝马迹中推理出正确结论的。成功侦破红发会奇案之后，Holmes和Dr. Waston迎来了又一起神秘案件——银色马失踪之谜。
article_info.share_words: For a whole day my companion had walked up and down the room with an expression of intense concentration on his face, filling his pipe and smoking it and filling it again with the strongest black tobacco, and absolutely deaf to any of my questions or remarks.

question.en: What happened to the horse and the trainer?

options.cn: 马失踪了，驯马师被杀害了。
options.en: The horse disappeared and the trainer was murdered.

analysis: 文中提到：“the remarkable disappearance of the favorite for the Wessex Cup, and the tragic murder of its trainer.”所以选C。

question.cn: 英国各地的人们都在谈论着的一件事是关于？
question.en: What was the topic of conversation throughout all of England?

options.cn: Holmes的分析能力受到了质疑。
options.en: Holmes’s powers of analysis were challenged.

options.cn: Silver Blaze失踪，驯马师被杀害。
options.en: Silver Blaze disappeared and its trainer was murdered.
Holmes decided to move to live in King's Pyland.

analysis: 文中先后提到：“This extraordinary case, which was the one topic of conversation throughout all of England” “And that was the remarkable disappearance of the favorite for the Wessex Cup, and the tragic murder of its trainer.”所以选B。

question.cn: Ross上校和Gregory督察为什么给Holmes发电报？
question.en: Why did Colonel Ross and Inspector Gregory send telegrams to Holmes?

options.cn: 他们希望Holmes为Silver Blaze报仇，杀死凶手。
options.en: They wanted Holmes to avenge for Silver Blaze and killed the murderer.

options.cn: 他们希望Holmes不要再苦苦思索这起案件了，因为凶手已经被找到了。
options.en: They wanted Holmes to stop thinking over the case because the murderer had been found.

options.cn: 他们希望Holmes能帮助调查这起案件。
options.en: They wanted Holmes to help investigate the case.

analysis: 文中Holmes说：“On Tuesday evening I received telegrams from both Colonel Ross, the owner of the horse, and Inspector Gregory, who is looking after the case, inviting my co-operation.”所以选C。

question.cn: Holmes昨天为什么没有去King’s Pyland？
question.en: Why didn’t Holmes go to King’s Pyland yesterday?

options.cn: 他认为这起案件不关他的事。
options.en: He thought the case was none of his business.

options.cn: 他期待马和凶手都能在昨天被找到。
options.en: He expected that both the horse and the murderer could had been found yesterday.
He was tired and slept for a whole day.

analysis: 文中Holmes说：“Because I made a mistake. . . I could not believe it possible that the most remarkable horse in England could long remain hidden, especially in so remote and lonely a place as the north of Dartmoor. From hour to hour yesterday I expected to hear that he had been found, and that the man who had taken him was the murderer of John Straker.”所以选B。
文中提到“The trainer, John Straker, is a retired jockey who rode for Colonel Ross before he became too heavy to ride in races.”所以选B。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第52天
